Precedent: Special counsel reports on allegations of wrongdoing by a president are released in full to Congress.
 
Unprecedented: A president‚Äôs political appointee releases only his interpretation of the report.
 
#ReleaseTheFullReport, Mr. Barr.
Congress must evaluate the report without delay and continue our Constitutionally-based oversight of Mr. Trump and his administration. The American people demand ‚Äì and deserve ‚Äì no less.
My concern about Mr. Trump‚Äôs presidency remains broad and deep, involving not only obstruction of justice but also the Emoluments Clause, campaign finance violations, freedom of the press and more.
The findings also spawned numerous other investigations in the courts and Congress into Mr. Trump, his campaign, administration and associates.

In the course of his investigation, Mr. Mueller filed nearly 200 charges against 34 people and three Russian companies, and seven people submitted guilty pleas and five have been sentenced for their crimes.

Given Mr. Barr‚Äôs plainly stated animus against the independent counsel process, Congress and the American people must clearly make their own judgment ‚Äì once we have access to the report and the work supporting it.

I am relieved that Mr. Mueller concluded that a president of the United States did not conspire in that interference, but I am deeply troubled that he could not exonerate Mr. Trump on obstruction of justice.
According to Attorney General Barr‚Äôs brief letter, Mr. Mueller concluded that Russia did, in fact, interfere with our 2016 election.
The Mueller Report must be released to Congress and the American people ‚Äì in full and without delay.
